thread.title: Yours for £1: Two-bedroom terraced house unoccupied for a decade now on the market for a bargain
thread.title_full: Yours for £1: Two-bedroom terraced house unoccupied for a decade now on the market for a bargain

author: Richard Wheatstone
title: Yours for £1: Two-bedroom terraced house unoccupied for a decade now on the market for a bargain
text:
The house has gone up for auction at £1 (Photo: Robinson Estate Agents) Share Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
A run-down terraced house has gone on the market for less than a bottle of Coke - but you might need to get your hands dirty. 
The property in Sacriston, Durham, has been derelict for around 10 years but is on the same street as houses worth more than £100,000. 
But prospective buyers have been warned it will need around £30,000 to even make it habitable. 
The home - which boasts two bedrooms, an entrance hall, living room, kitchen-dining room and a rear porch - will be auctioned in April. 
Images of the house show the dated wallpaper, filthy carpets and broken furniture. Read More The two-bed terrace is in need of major renovation (Photo: Robinson Estate Agents) The property has been derelict for around 10 years (Photo: Robinson Estate Agents) 
But despite it's blemishes, the property boasts spacious rooms and many of its original features. 
Michael Hughes, manager for estate agents Robinsons which is auctioning off the property, said the property belonged to someone who died several years ago. 
He said: "It is on a nice terrace in a popular village which isn't far from Durham city centre, Chester-le-Street town centre and is near the A1. 
"The house could be really beautiful. Read More The house will need around £30,000 to be brought up to standard (Photo: Robinson Estate Agents) It is estimated to fetch between £30,000 and £40,000 at auction (Photo: Robinson Estate Agents) 
"The market is very buoyant in the North East at the moment but we decided to put the house up for auction for £1 as it was hard to put a specific price on it. 
"This is the fairest way to get the best possible price and also allow anyone the opportunity to purchase it." 
It is thought that it will be sold for between £30,000 to £40,000. 
The auction will take place on April 4. Like us on Facebook
